description.narrative: To assist DAB to develop action plans for improved banking supervision and to establish key building blocks of financial sector infrastructure: payment system, movable collateral registry, and public credit registry.

title.narrative: Number of commercial banks? staff trained in AIBF reaches 6,000 by end of project

baseline.value: Low: a, e, f; Med-low: d; n.a. b, c

target.value: Med-High: a, b, d, f; Med-Low: c, e

actual.value: Low: a, e, f; Med-low: d; n.a. b, c

title.narrative: RTGS operational and transactions settled in real time by end of project

actual.value: RTGS installed and functional. It is integrated with all operating banksATS/RTGS was installed within DAB finalized testing withall commercial banks. As at October 2019, about 480 transactions has been processed in ATS Test environement successfully. The fullSTP system in place for settlement of interbank payment and will contribute to decrease cost of transaction reduce delays insettlement and improves transparency also bring efficiency. DAB current interbank payment systems statistic 2019:Interbanktransactions trough (ACSS) system 2019.101811 Transactions for the Value of total 440,266,143,645 AFN41796 Transactions for theValue of total 5,016,603,373 USD1612 Transactions for the Value of total 49,724,560.91 EURCheque transactions trough (CCH) system2019.982 Transactions for the Value of total 263,386,820 AFN837 Transactions for the Value of total 9,231,499 USD4 Transactionsfor the Value of total 125,930 EURGovernment Revenue Collection transactions trough (ICPSS)

title.narrative: Actions plans developed, with initial implementation monitored,for the ten banks audited

actual.value: The ten audits were delivered to DAB. Following the audit of these banks, DAB's FSD developed Weak Bank Strategy and Action Plan toimprove ratings and overall performances and conditions of these weak banks. In the last 5 years, total 3 strategies and actionplans were developed where two of these plans were successfully implemented and the third one which covers March 2019 till March2021 is in the implementation phase.

title.narrative: Audit reports completed highlighting strengths and weaknesses of each bank

target.value: System goes live and, on an ongoing basis, processes over 80% of domestic interbank/inter-institution payment card and mobile moneytransactions

actual.value: Implementation of interbank card system underway. The Afghan Payment system platform was inaugurated on April 26, 2016. Discussionsongoing to increase number of participants. The system is live. (6 banks)

title.narrative: Payment system conforms to international norms

actual.value: ATS, APS and CSD systems were installed and functional. It is currently in accordance to the BIS 10 Core Principles forSystemically Important Payments Systems (CPSS) (BIS, 2001):1. The international norms requires: The system should have awell-founded legal basis under all relevant jurisdictions. In this regard the DBA law has given sufficient power to DAB forestablishment, maintaining, promoting sound and efficient payment system and participating in it, so DAB has developed and approvedthe following regulations: Regulation on (DPO) Domestic Payments Operations in Afghanistan (2010) Regulation on (EFT)Electronic Fund Transfers (2015) Regulation on (PSOs) Payment system and payment system operators (2016) Regulation on (EMIs)Electronic Money Institutions (2016) Regulation on (MSPs) Money Service Providers (2016) Regulation on (PSPs) Licensing andOversight of Payment and Securities Transfer Systems (Payment Service Operator) and Policy framework for (RTGS – ACH)(201

baseline.value: T+1 for Kabul area and T+3 for other areas

actual.value: Settlements through ATS, banks finalized testing the 8 payment types in the system trough TMSX – WBPP and all interbank RTGStransactions settles between participant banks in real time gross bases. Settlements through APS, Card transactions performedthrough interoperability (shared ATM networks) are prepared and shared with the APS members on daily bases, but due to low volumeof transactions, such reports are sent to DAB twice a week. As usage pick up the frequency will be revised.

title.narrative: of which the number of female commercial bank staff trained
of which the number of female commercial bank staff trained
Percentage increase in the number of on-site and off-site examinations by the department
Increase in the number of creditreports sent by the Public Credit Registry to commercial banks
Increase in the number of items of collateral registered in the Collateral Registry
Approval by DAB of financial sector regulations ensuring consistency with international standards

baseline.value: Afghanistan financial sector regulations not fully aligned with international standards

actual.value: A new banking law and AML/CFT regulations were approved. Procurement of TA for Financial Supervision Department (FSD) completed andimplementation started in Nov, 2017. The FSD TA suffered some hick ups; however, the activity was concluded in Jan 2020 and thefirm provided several deliverables on potential regulatory reforms. This contributed to some regulatory reforms that DAB adoptedparticularly on CAMELS criteria, accepting partial credit guarantees as collateral. DAB is currently assessing further reforms inview of the TA outcomes. The following regulations were developed and introduced: • Legal Assessment Report against InternationalStandards• Regulation on Licensing and Oversight of Payment and Securities Transfer Systems, and of Money ServiceProviders• Regulation on Licensing and Oversight of Payment and Securities Transfer Systems• Regulation on Licensing andOversight of Money Service Providers• DAB General Guidelines on Retail Payments Instruments• Regulation on

title.narrative: Effective Financial Supervision Department (FSD) organization with training processes in place to ensure sustainable capacity development

actual.value: Procurement of TA for Financial Supervision Department completed and implementation started in Nov, 2017. This activity sufferedmany delays and was only partially delivered. The outcomes of the TA on developing FSD's capacity including developing of trainingprocesses was therefore suboptimal. .

title.narrative: Enhanced operational efficiency of DAB staff : percentage reduction in time spent to prepare DAB balance sheet

Increased transparency through the adoption of international central bank accounting and auditing standards

baseline.value: Financial statements prepared based on local accounting standards

target.value: DAB financial statements for the year ended in 2018 prepared in accordance with IFRS (as applicable in 2016)

actual.value: Financial statements prepared based on local accounting standards. The delay in the procurement process for “adoption of IFRSstandards” project has delayed the adoption of the IFRS 9.
